title: Snowfall Amounts
question_text:
A meteorologist in a small town has been keeping track of annual snowfall amounts for the last $65\text{ years}$. The annual snowfall has an average of $54\text{ inches}$ with a standard deviation of $9.8\text{ inches}$. This year a local citizen claimed the town received $124.5\text{ inches}$ of snow.
Based on this information, one can conclude

choices.text: A mistake was likely made in recording snowfall amounts.
This year was surprisingly snowy but is not a huge abnormality.
The interquartile range must be well over $9.8\text{ inches}$.
Before the point $124.5$ was added, this distribution was right skewed.
The median will be greater than the mean for this distribution.

solution:
Based off of the mean and standard deviation, this yearâ€™s snowfall amounts put the town $7.19\text{ standard deviations}$ above the mean.

$$\dfrac{(124.5-54)}{9.8} = 7.19$$

One should know that anything $4$ to $5\text{ standard deviations}$ away from the mean is extremely unlikely. It is likely a mistake was made in recording the snowfall totals this year.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'B' is incorrect; this is a huge abnormality, being $7.19\text{ standard deviations}$ above the mean.

Choice 'C' is incorrect; while both IQR and standard deviation are measures of spread, knowing the standard deviation is $9.8$ does not necessarily tell anything about the IQR.

Choice 'D' is incorrect; while snowfall totals could be right skewed, from the information given (mean, standard deviation), one does not necessarily know that this distribution is right skewed.

Choice 'E' is incorrect; while this statement could be true, one cannot determine where the median is relative to the mean when given only the mean and standard deviation.
